Governors are taking into mind the risk of spreading the virus to decide which places are the safest to open up first. Based on the graph, the safest places to open first would be outdoor places with greater contact because if you’re outside, such as at the park or the beach, there’s less interacting with people and touching other surfaces, and you’re able to spread out more, depending on the amount of people. Gyms should open last because you're required to share the equipment, and social distancing can be difficult as well as cleaning the facility and machines each time. name: Quinn Bernal
comment info:
After reading the new information, the only thing that was different the mention of another graph showing  the relationship between the total weekly visits per square foot and average length in time of visits for specific businesses and public places. According to the Stat Nuggets, in the reopening graph, the diameter of the bubble is representative of the size of the business sector or public place as calculated by the product of the average weekly visits and the total number of establishments. The other two variables are the rating of the degree of contact, as measured by the interaction with people and touched shared surfaces, defined by the horizontal x-axis, and the rating of how much of the activity is indoors (versus outside) is located on the vertical y-axis. 
The association was inconclusive due to the lack of information and experimentation, and there isn't any percent change due to the lack of a big difference in data.

name: Simone Cronier
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: Once reading the reveal article that goes along with the bubble chart, I was shocked to learn how difficult it really is for state governments to decide which stories they should open. On one hand, opening low risk stores sounds like a great idea, but it’s also showing favoritism and not allowing other stores to have business. And even if the governor of a state starts opening low risk stores, what qualifies as a low risk store anyway? In the article, it says that the governor of California is trying to open bookstores, toy stores, and sporting goods, but those all fit into the high risk category. And it gets even harder when adding in the aspect of concentration in businesses. A breakfast restaurant will have all it’s customers come in in the morning, while a breakfast, lunch, and diner restaurant will have customers coming in throughout the whole day. If it’s already difficult to categorize the risk of going to attractions, I can’t imagine how hard it’s going to be to categorize the risk of types of specific buildings like restaurants.

name: Simone Cronier
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
“Ranking Suddenly Dangerous Buildings.”

Just looking at the graph, I can already see a ton of overlap in medium contact indoor activities. Strangely though, even though sit-down restaurants and malls closed down relatively early, the North Carolina state government left the fast food restaurants open. I’m glad they did though, it’s hard finding food places when all the restaurants are closed. I also remember that gyms, amusement parks, and nail salons were all closed very early on in the pandemic. Though they all lie on different places on the indoors to outdoors scale, I can see that they’re all past level 6 of contact. This is very different from parks and museums which didn’t close as early on. It wasn’t until bored people started flocking to the parks that they closed down. I don’t think that should have happened because parks are so low on the contact scale and are also situated outside. This means that any virus germs that a person could have wouldn’t be passed along as easily as germs in an indoor location would. The same thing happened with the beaches even though they’re not on this graph. 

In order for the state government to start opening things safely, I suggest going from the bottom left corner and ending in the top right corner. Opening buildings that contain activities that are outdoors and alone to those that are indoors and interconnected is the best course of action. Although I do hope that restaurants start opening up again soon. Fingers crossed.

name: Moderator
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Each state has been determining when they should start reopening up for businesses and public places.  Which places have the lowest contagion risk?  What order should they be reopened? 

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these visual representations and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

This is our final graph for the school year. Please visit our archive at www.nytimes.com/column/whats-going-on-in-this-graph to find dozens of other graphs you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter at www.nytimes.com/newsletters/signup/LN for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new graphs.  

Search for our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom?” for indices by context and by type of graph.  The link for the Stat Nuggets archives is tinyurl.com/StatNuggets.

Keep noticing and wondering.  Stay tuned.
